author: J. Lane

review: I bought this device under the pretense that it would cast audio/video streaming off of the internet from my computer to my TV.  And, it did, right after I bought it, a couple of months ago.  "It was slick."  I bought it to stream ESPN (or any other) sports from my MAC desktop to my TV.  I tried to cast streaming a short time ago, and it wouldn't do it, anymore.  I tried everything imaginable to resolve the malfunction, to no avail.  I called Google Tech Support, they ran me through a series of tests, and finally told me that there was nothing wrong with my device, my equipment, my software, or my internet speed.  The problem was at their end with the software of this BETA version.  It would work okay for YouTube, but I couldn't care less about YouTube and some of that other stuff.  It won't cast my streaming off of the internet, which is why I bought it.  I was told that the engineers would eventually get this problem ironed out, but what good does that do me?  I tried it again, just last night--it still doesn't work.  As far as I am concerned, Google Chromecast is a major failure, and a piece of junk.  And I'm out $35.
author: Shellcaptain

review: The name implies synergy with the Chrome browser, but casting is not supported on Chrome for Android. It would not connect to our non-broadcast Wi-Fi network SSID. Lack of DLNA support requires installation of third-party media servers, requiring time and additional setup. We already have Netflix and other services available through our TV, DVD player, and WD TV Live Media Player. Chromecast added no new features for our use.

review: I have a setup where all my music that I download is instantly uploaded to Google Play Music which I can stream to my Chromecast connected to my main TV, which is connected to my stereo system. My setup seems complicated, but making music play on my TV was dead simple. This device is something everyone can afford and everyone should have.Pros:Extremely simple to setup and use.Small and unobtrusive design.Works on any screen with HDMICons:SDK not released yet, so a lot of potential waiting to happen.A few issues here and there with disconnecting, but rarely happens.HDMI doesn't power the device, but I'm not so certain it could be.Overall: If you're considering buying this device, do it. It's better and easier than using a Roku, unless you don't have a smartphone or some computer. Any iPhone, Android device, or PC/Mac is able to push content to this device.
